newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU recalls officials, no progress in US meat talks.
newsitem.headline: EU recalls officials, no progress in US meat talks.

text.p: EU Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler has recalled negotiators from Washington because of lack of progress in settling a trade dispute over meat inspection rules, a Commission spokesman said on Friday.

"No progress was made," agriculture spokesman Gerard Kiely told a news briefing, adding, "Fischler will call the USDA secretary (Glickman) to make it clear that the EU's room for manoeuvre has been exhausted."
The main obstacle to agreement is over poultry hygiene standards with the EU saying that the U.S. method of decontaminating chicken carcasses by dipping them in chlorinated water is unacceptable.

"Either the U.S. comes back to us saying we can have a deal on the basis of what's on the table or else there isn't much point in continuing the negotiations," Kiely said. "If the U.S. doesn't move we don't see much hope of finding an agreement."
On April 1, the EU started to block U.S. poultry imports worth some $50 million annually.
The U.S. has warned that if no "veterinary equivalency" agreement is reached by an end-month deadline, it will block imports of EU meat, mainly Danish pigmeat, worth some $300 million annually.
On Thursday, senior U.S. negotiators said some progress had been made in the difficult talks and they were not giving up.
